p: Since both human H1N1 and H3N2 viruses feature high-mannose glycans at potentially key positions within the HA head domain, we investigated the ability of GNL to inhibit receptor binding and neutralize infection in vitro using cell culture microneutralization (MN) and hemagglutination inhibition (HAI) assays ( Figures 3 and S2). Relative to a specific anti-H1 monoclonal antibody (mAb) with known MN function, GNL failed to protect Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells from infection with Cal/04 (H1N1) virus, suggesting that the observed high-mannose glycans are located some distance from the RBS ( Figure 3 A). Conversely, however, GNL showed potent neutralization of Per/09 (A/Perth/16/2009; H3N2) compared with a control anti-H3 mAb ( Figure 3A), indicating that at least one oligomannose site in the more-heavily glycosylated H3 head is likely suitably positioned for strong inhibition of receptor engagement. Comparable data were also obtained for HAI assays, where GNL showed successful inhibition of Per/09 only, while comparison of GNL with a panel of lectins with diverse glycan specificities revealed potent neutralization to be confined to high-mannose-targeted reagents only ( Figure S2).
